Î£_1 function

Î£1â€‹(E) can be done in 6 lookups.

To achieve this we first split E into pieces (a,b,c,d), of lengths (6,5,14,7) bits respectively counting from the little end. At the same time we obtain the spread forms of these pieces. This can all be done in two PLONK rows, because the 7 and 14-bit pieces can be handled using spread lookups, the 5-bit piece can be split into 3 and 2-bit subpieces, and the 6-bit piece can be split into 2âˆ—3-bit subpieces. The four small pieces can be range-checked by polynomial constraints in parallel with the two lookups, two small pieces in each row. The spread forms of these small pieces are found by interpolation.

Note that the splitting into pieces can be combined with the reduction of Enewâ€‹, i.e. no extra lookups are needed for the latter. In the last round we reduce Enewâ€‹ after adding the feedforward (requiring a carry of up to 6 which is fine).

Message scheduling

We apply Ïƒ0â€‹ to W1..48â€‹, and Ïƒ1â€‹ to W14..61â€‹. In order to avoid redundant applications of spread, we can merge the splitting into pieces for Ïƒ0â€‹ and Ïƒ1â€‹ in the case of W14..48â€‹. Merging the piece lengths (3,4,11,14) and (10,7,2,13) gives pieces of lengths (3,4,3,7,1,1,13).

If we can do the merged split in 3 rows (as opposed to a total of 4 rows when splitting for Ïƒ0â€‹ and Ïƒ1â€‹ separately), we save 35 rows.

These might even be doable in 2 rows; not sure. â€”Daira

We can merge the reduction mod 232 of W16..61â€‹ into their splitting when they are used to compute subsequent words, similarly to what we did for A and E in the round function.

We will still need to reduce W62..63â€‹ since they are not split. (Technically we could leave them unreduced since they will be reduced later when they are used to compute Anewâ€‹ and Enewâ€‹ -- but that would require handling a carry of up to 10 rather than 6, so it's not worth the complexity.)

The resulting message schedule cost is:

  • 2 rows to constrain W0â€‹ to 32 bits
    • This is technically optional, but let's do it for robustness, since the rest of the input is constrained for free.
  • 13âˆ—2 rows to split W1..13â€‹ into (3,4,11,14)-bit pieces
  • 35âˆ—3 rows to split W14..48â€‹ into (3,4,3,7,1,1,13)-bit pieces (merged with a reduction for W16..48â€‹)
  • 13âˆ—2 rows to split W49..61â€‹ into (10,7,2,13)-bit pieces (merged with a reduction)
  • 4âˆ—48 rows to extract the results of Ïƒ0â€‹ for W1..48â€‹
  • 4âˆ—48 rows to extract the results of Ïƒ1â€‹ for W14..61â€‹
  • 2âˆ—2 rows to reduce W62..63â€‹
  • =547 rows.

Overall cost

For each round:

  • 8 rows for Ch
  • 4 rows for Maj
  • 6 rows for Î£0â€‹
  • 6 rows for Î£1â€‹
  • reduce6â€‹ and reduce7â€‹ are always free
  • =24 per round

This gives 24âˆ—64=1792 rows for all of "step 3", to which we need to add:

  • 547 rows for message scheduling
  • 2âˆ—8 rows for 8 reductions mod 232 in "step 4"

giving a total of 2099 rows.

Background Material

This section covers the background material required to understand the Halo 2 proving system. It is targeted at an ELI15 (Explain It Like I'm 15) level; if you think anything could do with additional explanation, let us know!

Fields

A fundamental component of many cryptographic protocols is the algebraic structure known as a field. Fields are sets of objects (usually numbers) with two associated binary operators + and Ã— such that various field axioms hold. The real numbers R are an example of a field with uncountably many elements.

Halo makes use of finite fields which have a finite number of elements. Finite fields are fully classified as follows:

  • if F is a finite field, it contains âˆ£Fâˆ£=pk elements for some integer kâ‰¥1 and some prime p;
  • any two finite fields with the same number of elements are isomorphic. In particular, all of the arithmetic in a prime field Fpâ€‹ is isomorphic to addition and multiplication of integers modulo p, i.e. in Zpâ€‹. This is why we often refer to p as the modulus.

We'll write a field as Fqâ€‹ where q=pk. The prime p is called its characteristic. In the cases where k>1 the field Fqâ€‹ is a k-degree extension of the field Fpâ€‹. (By analogy, the complex numbers C=R(i) are an extension of the real numbers.) However, in Halo we do not use extension fields. Whenever we write Fpâ€‹ we are referring to what we call a prime field which has a prime p number of elements, i.e. k=1.

Important notes:

  • There are two special elements in any field: 0, the additive identity, and 1, the multiplicative identity.
  • The least significant bit of a field element, when represented as an integer in binary format, can be interpreted as its "sign" to help distinguish it from its additive inverse (negation). This is because for some nonzero element a which has a least significant bit 0 we have that âˆ’a=pâˆ’a has a least significant bit 1, and vice versa. We could also use whether or not an element is larger than (pâˆ’1)/2 to give it a "sign."

Finite fields will be useful later for constructing polynomials and elliptic curves. Elliptic curves are examples of groups, which we discuss next.

Groups

Groups are simpler and more limited than fields; they have only one binary operator â‹… and fewer axioms. They also have an identity, which we'll denote as 1.

Any non-zero element a in a group has an inverse b=aâˆ’1, which is the unique element b such that aâ‹…b=1.

For example, the set of nonzero elements of Fpâ€‹ forms a group, where the group operation is given by multiplication on the field.

(aside) Additive vs multiplicative notation

If â‹… is written as Ã— or omitted (i.e. aâ‹…b written as ab), the identity as 1, and inversion as aâˆ’1, as we did above, then we say that the group is "written multiplicatively". If â‹… is written as +, the identity as 0 or O, and inversion as âˆ’a, then we say it is "written additively".

It's conventional to use additive notation for elliptic curve groups, and multiplicative notation when the elements come from a finite field.

When additive notation is used, we also write

[k]A=kÂ timesA+A+â‹¯+Aâ€‹â€‹

for nonnegative k and call this "scalar multiplication"; we also often use uppercase letters for variables denoting group elements. When multiplicative notation is used, we also write

ak=kÂ timesaÃ—aÃ—â‹¯Ã—aâ€‹â€‹

and call this "exponentiation". In either case we call the scalar k such that [k]g=a or gk=a the "discrete logarithm" of a to base g. We can extend scalars to negative integers by inversion, i.e. [âˆ’k]A+[k]A=O or aâˆ’kÃ—ak=1.

The order of an element a of a finite group is defined as the smallest positive integer k such that ak=1 (in multiplicative notation) or [k]a=O (in additive notation). The order of the group is the number of elements.

Groups always have a generating set, which is a set of elements such that we can produce any element of the group as (in multiplicative terminology) a product of powers of those elements. So if the generating set is g1..kâ€‹, we can produce any element of the group as i=1âˆkâ€‹giaiâ€‹â€‹. There can be many different generating sets for a given group.

A group is called cyclic if it has a (not necessarily unique) generating set with only a single element â€” call it g. In that case we can say that g generates the group, and that the order of g is the order of the group.

Any finite cyclic group G of order n is isomorphic to the integers modulo n (denoted Z/nZ), such that:

  • the operation â‹… in G corresponds to addition modulo n;
  • the identity in G corresponds to 0;
  • some generator gâˆˆG corresponds to 1.

Given a generator g, the isomorphism is always easy to compute in the Z/nZâ†’G direction; it is just aâ†¦ga (or in additive notation, aâ†¦[a]g). It may be difficult in general to compute in the Gâ†’Z/nZ direction; we'll discuss this further when we come to elliptic curves.

If the order n of a finite group is prime, then the group is cyclic, and every non-identity element is a generator.

The multiplicative group of a finite field

We use the notation FpÃ—â€‹ for the multiplicative group (i.e. the group operation is multiplication in Fpâ€‹) over the set Fpâ€‹âˆ’{0}.

A quick way of obtaining the inverse in FpÃ—â€‹ is aâˆ’1=apâˆ’2. The reason for this stems from Fermat's little theorem, which states that ap=a(modp) for any integer a. If a is nonzero, we can divide by a twice to get apâˆ’2=aâˆ’1.

Let's assume that Î± is a generator of FpÃ—â€‹, so it has order pâˆ’1 (equal to the number of elements in FpÃ—â€‹). Therefore, for any element in aâˆˆFpÃ—â€‹ there is a unique integer iâˆˆ{0..pâˆ’2} such that a=Î±i.

Notice that aÃ—b where a,bâˆˆFpÃ—â€‹ can really be interpreted as Î±iÃ—Î±j where a=Î±i and b=Î±j. Indeed, it holds that Î±iÃ—Î±j=Î±i+j for all 0â‰¤i,j<pâˆ’1. As a result the multiplication of nonzero field elements can be interpreted as addition modulo pâˆ’1 with respect to some fixed generator Î±. The addition just happens "in the exponent."

This is another way to look at where apâˆ’2 comes from for computing inverses in the field:

pâˆ’2â‰¡âˆ’1(modpâˆ’1),

so apâˆ’2=aâˆ’1.

Montgomery's Trick

Montgomery's trick, named after Peter Montgomery (RIP) is a way to compute many group inversions at the same time. It is commonly used to compute inversions in FpÃ—â€‹, which are quite computationally expensive compared to multiplication.

Imagine we need to compute the inverses of three nonzero elements a,b,câˆˆFpÃ—â€‹. Instead, we'll compute the products x=ab and y=xc=abc, and compute the inversion

z=ypâˆ’2=abc1â€‹.

We can now multiply z by x to obtain c1â€‹ and multiply z by c to obtain ab1â€‹, which we can then multiply by a,b to obtain their respective inverses.

This technique generalizes to arbitrary numbers of group elements with just a single inversion necessary.

Multiplicative subgroups

A subgroup of a group G with operation â‹…, is a subset of elements of G that also form a group under â‹….

In the previous section we said that Î± is a generator of the (pâˆ’1)-order multiplicative group FpÃ—â€‹. This group has composite order, and so by the Chinese remainder theorem1 it has strict subgroups. As an example let's imagine that p=11, and so pâˆ’1 factors into 5â‹…2. Thus, there is a generator Î² of the 5-order subgroup and a generator Î³ of the 2-order subgroup. All elements in FpÃ—â€‹, therefore, can be written uniquely as Î²iâ‹…Î³j for some i (modulo 5) and some j (modulo 2).

If we have a=Î²iâ‹…Î³j notice what happens when we compute

a5=(Î²iâ‹…Î³j)5=Î²iâ‹…5â‹…Î³jâ‹…5=Î²0â‹…Î³jâ‹…5=Î³jâ‹…5;

we have effectively "killed" the 5-order subgroup component, producing a value in the 2-order subgroup.

Lagrange's theorem (group theory) states that the order of any subgroup H of a finite group G divides the order of G. Therefore, the order of any subgroup of FpÃ—â€‹ must divide pâˆ’1.

PLONK-based proving systems like Halo 2 are more convenient to use with fields that have a large number of multiplicative subgroups with a "smooth" distribution (which makes the performance cliffs smaller and more granular as circuit sizes increase). The Pallas and Vesta curves specifically have primes of the form

Tâ‹…2S=pâˆ’1

with S=32 and T odd (i.e. pâˆ’1 has 32 lower zero-bits). This means they have multiplicative subgroups of order 2k for all kâ‰¤32. These 2-adic subgroups are nice for efficient FFTs, as well as enabling a wide variety of circuit sizes.

Square roots

In a field Fpâ€‹ exactly half of all nonzero elements are squares; the remainder are non-squares or "quadratic non-residues". In order to see why, consider an Î± that generates the 2-order multiplicative subgroup of FpÃ—â€‹ (this exists because pâˆ’1 is divisible by 2 since p is a prime greater than 2) and Î² that generates the t-order multiplicative subgroup of FpÃ—â€‹ where pâˆ’1=2t. Then every element aâˆˆFpÃ—â€‹ can be written uniquely as Î±iâ‹…Î²j with iâˆˆZ2â€‹ and jâˆˆZtâ€‹. Half of all elements will have i=0 and the other half will have i=1.

Let's consider the simple case where pâ‰¡3(mod4) and so t is odd (if t is even, then pâˆ’1 would be divisible by 4, which contradicts p being 3(mod4)). If aâˆˆFpÃ—â€‹ is a square, then there must exist b=Î±iâ‹…Î²j such that b2=a. But this means that

a=(Î±iâ‹…Î²j)2=Î±2iâ‹…Î²2j=Î²2j.

In other words, all squares in this particular field do not generate the 2-order multiplicative subgroup, and so since half of the elements generate the 2-order subgroup then at most half of the elements are square. In fact exactly half of the elements are square (since squaring each nonsquare element gives a unique square). This means we can assume all squares can be written as Î²m for some m, and therefore finding the square root is a matter of exponentiating by 2âˆ’1(modt).

In the event that pâ‰¡1(mod4) then things get more complicated because 2âˆ’1(modt) does not exist. Let's write pâˆ’1 as 2kâ‹…t with t odd. The case k=0 is impossible, and the case k=1 is what we already described, so consider kâ‰¥2. Î± generates a 2k-order multiplicative subgroup and Î² generates the odd t-order multiplicative subgroup. Then every element aâˆˆFpÃ—â€‹ can be written as Î±iâ‹…Î²j for iâˆˆZ2kâ€‹ and jâˆˆZtâ€‹. If the element is a square, then there exists some b=aâ€‹ which can be written b=Î±iâ€²â‹…Î²jâ€² for iâ€²âˆˆZ2kâ€‹ and jâ€²âˆˆZtâ€‹. This means that a=b2=Î±2iâ€²â‹…Î²2jâ€², therefore we have iâ‰¡2iâ€²(mod2k), and jâ‰¡2jâ€²(modt). i would have to be even in this case because otherwise it would be impossible to have iâ‰¡2iâ€²(mod2k) for any iâ€². In the case that a is not a square, then i is odd, and so half of all elements are squares.

In order to compute the square root, we can first raise the element a=Î±iâ‹…Î²j to the power t to "kill" the t-order component, giving

at=Î±it(mod2)kâ‹…Î²jt(modt)=Î±it(mod2)k

and then raise this result to the power tâˆ’1(mod2k) to undo the effect of the original exponentiation on the 2k-order component:

(Î±itmod2k)tâˆ’1(mod2k)=Î±i

(since t is relatively prime to 2k). This leaves bare the Î±i value which we can trivially handle. We can similarly kill the 2k-order component to obtain Î²jâ‹…2âˆ’1(modt), and put the values together to obtain the square root.

It turns out that in the cases k=2,3 there are simpler algorithms that merge several of these exponentiations together for efficiency. For other values of k, the only known way is to manually extract i by squaring until you obtain the identity for every single bit of i. This is the essence of the Tonelli-Shanks square root algorithm and describes the general strategy. (There is another square root algorithm that uses quadratic extension fields, but it doesn't pay off in efficiency until the prime becomes quite large.)

Roots of unity

In the previous sections we wrote pâˆ’1=2kâ‹…t with t odd, and stated that an element Î±âˆˆFpÃ—â€‹ generated the 2k-order subgroup. For convenience, let's denote n:=2k. The elements {1,Î±,â€¦,Î±nâˆ’1} are known as the nth roots of unity.

The primitive root of unity, Ï‰, is an nth root of unity such that Ï‰iî€ =1 except when iâ‰¡0(modn).

Important notes:

  • If Î± is an nth root of unity, Î± satisfies Î±nâˆ’1=0. If Î±î€ =1, then 1+Î±+Î±2+â‹¯+Î±nâˆ’1=0.

  • Equivalently, the roots of unity are solutions to the equation Xnâˆ’1=(Xâˆ’1)(Xâˆ’Î±)(Xâˆ’Î±2)â‹¯(Xâˆ’Î±nâˆ’1).

  • Ï‰2nâ€‹+i=âˆ’Ï‰iâ€‹ ("Negation lemma"). Proof: Ï‰n=1â€‹âŸ¹Ï‰nâˆ’1=0âŸ¹(Ï‰n/2+1)(Ï‰n/2âˆ’1)=0.â€‹ Since the order of Ï‰ is n, Ï‰n/2î€ =1. Therefore, Ï‰n/2=âˆ’1.

  • (Ï‰2nâ€‹+i)2=(Ï‰i)2â€‹ ("Halving lemma"). Proof: (Ï‰2nâ€‹+i)2=Ï‰n+2i=Ï‰nâ‹…Ï‰2i=Ï‰2i=(Ï‰i)2. In other words, if we square each element in the nth roots of unity, we would get back only half the elements, {(Ï‰niâ€‹)2}={Ï‰n/2â€‹} (i.e. the 2nâ€‹th roots of unity). There is a two-to-one mapping between the elements and their squares.

Polynomials

Let A(X) be a polynomial over Fpâ€‹ with formal indeterminate X. As an example,

A(X)=a0â€‹+a1â€‹X+a2â€‹X2+a3â€‹X3

defines a degree-3 polynomial. a0â€‹ is referred to as the constant term. Polynomials of degree nâˆ’1 have n coefficients. We will often want to compute the result of replacing the formal indeterminate X with some concrete value x, which we denote by A(x).

In mathematics this is commonly referred to as "evaluating A(X) at a point x". The word "point" here stems from the geometrical usage of polynomials in the form y=A(x), where (x,y) is the coordinate of a point in two-dimensional space. However, the polynomials we deal with are almost always constrained to equal zero, and x will be an element of some field. This should not be confused with points on an elliptic curve, which we also make use of, but never in the context of polynomial evaluation.

Important notes:

  • Multiplication of polynomials produces a product polynomial that is the sum of the degrees of its factors. Polynomial division subtracts from the degree. deg(A(X)B(X))=deg(A(X))+deg(B(X)), deg(A(X)/B(X))=deg(A(X))âˆ’deg(B(X)).
  • Given a polynomial A(X) of degree nâˆ’1, if we obtain n evaluations of the polynomial at distinct points then these evaluations perfectly define the polynomial. In other words, given these evaluations we can obtain a unique polynomial A(X) of degree nâˆ’1 via polynomial interpolation.
  • [a0â€‹,a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâˆ’1â€‹] is the coefficient representation of the polynomial A(X). Equivalently, we could use its evaluation representation [(x0â€‹,A(x0â€‹)),(x1â€‹,A(x1â€‹)),â‹¯,(xnâˆ’1â€‹,A(xnâˆ’1â€‹))] at n distinct points. Either representation uniquely specifies the same polynomial.

(aside) Horner's rule

Horner's rule allows for efficient evaluation of a polynomial of degree nâˆ’1, using only nâˆ’1 multiplications and nâˆ’1 additions. It is the following identity: a0â€‹â€‹+a1â€‹X+a2â€‹X2+â‹¯+anâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1=a0â€‹+X(a1â€‹+X(a2â€‹+â‹¯+X(anâˆ’2â€‹+Xanâˆ’1â€‹))),â€‹

Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)

The FFT is an efficient way of converting between the coefficient and evaluation representations of a polynomial. It evaluates the polynomial at the nth roots of unity {Ï‰0,Ï‰1,â‹¯,Ï‰nâˆ’1}, where Ï‰ is a primitive nth root of unity. By exploiting symmetries in the roots of unity, each round of the FFT reduces the evaluation into a problem only half the size. Most commonly we use polynomials of length some power of two, n=2k, and apply the halving reduction recursively.

Motivation: Fast polynomial multiplication

In the coefficient representation, it takes O(n2) operations to multiply two polynomials A(X)â‹…B(X)=C(X):

A(X)B(X)C(X)â€‹=a0â€‹+a1â€‹X+a2â€‹X2+â‹¯+anâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1,=b0â€‹+b1â€‹X+b2â€‹X2+â‹¯+bnâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1,=a0â€‹â‹…(b0â€‹+b1â€‹X+b2â€‹X2+â‹¯+bnâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1)+a1â€‹Xâ‹…(b0â€‹+b1â€‹X+b2â€‹X2+â‹¯+bnâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1)+â‹¯+anâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1â‹…(b0â€‹+b1â€‹X+b2â€‹X2+â‹¯+bnâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1),â€‹

where each of the n terms in the first polynomial has to be multiplied by the n terms of the second polynomial.

In the evaluation representation, however, polynomial multiplication only requires O(n) operations:

ABCâ€‹:{(x0â€‹,A(x0â€‹)),(x1â€‹,A(x1â€‹)),â‹¯,(xnâˆ’1â€‹,A(xnâˆ’1â€‹))},:{(x0â€‹,B(x0â€‹)),(x1â€‹,B(x1â€‹)),â‹¯,(xnâˆ’1â€‹,B(xnâˆ’1â€‹))},:{(x0â€‹,A(x0â€‹)B(x0â€‹)),(x1â€‹,A(x1â€‹)B(x1â€‹)),â‹¯,(xnâˆ’1â€‹,A(xnâˆ’1â€‹)B(xnâˆ’1â€‹))},â€‹

where each evaluation is multiplied pointwise.

This suggests the following strategy for fast polynomial multiplication:

  1. Evaluate polynomials at all n points;
  2. Perform fast pointwise multiplication in the evaluation representation (O(n));
  3. Convert back to the coefficient representation.

The challenge now is how to evaluate and interpolate the polynomials efficiently. Naively, evaluating a polynomial at n points would require O(n2) operations (we use the O(n) Horner's rule at each point):

âŽ£âŽ¡â€‹A(1)A(Ï‰)A(Ï‰2)â‹®A(Ï‰nâˆ’1)â€‹âŽ¦âŽ¤â€‹=âŽ£âŽ¡â€‹111â‹®1â€‹1Ï‰Ï‰2â‹®Ï‰nâˆ’1â€‹1Ï‰2Ï‰2â‹…2â‹®Ï‰2(nâˆ’1)â€‹â€¦â€¦â€¦â‹¯â€‹1Ï‰nâˆ’1Ï‰2â‹…(nâˆ’1)â‹®Ï‰(nâˆ’1)2â€‹âŽ¦âŽ¤â€‹â‹…âŽ£âŽ¡â€‹a0â€‹a1â€‹a2â€‹â‹®anâˆ’1â€‹â€‹âŽ¦âŽ¤â€‹.

For convenience, we will denote the matrices above as: A^=VÏ‰â€‹â‹…A.

(A^ is known as the Discrete Fourier Transform of A; VÏ‰â€‹ is also called the Vandermonde matrix.)

The (radix-2) Cooley-Tukey algorithm

Our strategy is to divide a DFT of size n into two interleaved DFTs of size n/2. Given the polynomial A(X)=a0â€‹+a1â€‹X+a2â€‹X2+â‹¯+anâˆ’1â€‹Xnâˆ’1, we split it up into even and odd terms:

Aevenâ€‹Aoddâ€‹â€‹=a0â€‹+a2â€‹X+â‹¯+anâˆ’2â€‹X2nâ€‹âˆ’1,=a1â€‹+a3â€‹X+â‹¯+anâˆ’1â€‹X2nâ€‹âˆ’1.â€‹

To recover the original polynomial, we do A(X)=Aevenâ€‹(X2)+XAoddâ€‹(X2).

Trying this out on points Ï‰niâ€‹ and Ï‰n2nâ€‹+iâ€‹, iâˆˆ[0..2nâ€‹âˆ’1], we start to notice some symmetries:

A(Ï‰niâ€‹)A(Ï‰n2nâ€‹+iâ€‹)â€‹=Aevenâ€‹((Ï‰niâ€‹)2)+Ï‰niâ€‹Aoddâ€‹((Ï‰niâ€‹)2),=Aevenâ€‹((Ï‰n2nâ€‹+iâ€‹)2)+Ï‰n2nâ€‹+iâ€‹Aoddâ€‹((Ï‰n2nâ€‹+iâ€‹)2)=Aevenâ€‹((âˆ’Ï‰niâ€‹)2)âˆ’Ï‰niâ€‹Aoddâ€‹((âˆ’Ï‰niâ€‹)2)â†(negationÂ lemma)=Aevenâ€‹((Ï‰niâ€‹)2)âˆ’Ï‰niâ€‹Aoddâ€‹((Ï‰niâ€‹)2).â€‹

Notice that we are only evaluating Aevenâ€‹(X) and Aoddâ€‹(X) over half the domain {(Ï‰n0â€‹)2,(Ï‰nâ€‹)2,â‹¯,(Ï‰n2nâ€‹âˆ’1â€‹)2}={Ï‰n/2iâ€‹},i=[0..2nâ€‹âˆ’1] (halving lemma). This gives us all the terms we need to reconstruct A(X) over the full domain {Ï‰0,Ï‰,â‹¯,Ï‰nâˆ’1}: which means we have transformed a length-n DFT into two length-2nâ€‹ DFTs.

We choose n=2k to be a power of two (by zero-padding if needed), and apply this divide-and-conquer strategy recursively. By the Master Theorem1, this gives us an evaluation algorithm with O(nlog2â€‹n) operations, also known as the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT).

Inverse FFT

So we've evaluated our polynomials and multiplied them pointwise. What remains is to convert the product from the evaluation representation back to coefficient representation. To do this, we simply call the FFT on the evaluation representation. However, this time we also:

  • replace Ï‰i by Ï‰âˆ’i in the Vandermonde matrix, and
  • multiply our final result by a factor of 1/n.

In other words: A=n1â€‹VÏ‰âˆ’1â€‹â‹…A^.

(To understand why the inverse FFT has a similar form to the FFT, refer to Slide 13-1 of 2. The below image was also taken from 2.)

The Schwartz-Zippel lemma

The Schwartz-Zippel lemma informally states that "different polynomials are different at most points." Formally, it can be written as follows:

Let p(x1â€‹,x2â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) be a nonzero polynomial of n variables with degree d. Let S be a finite set of numbers with at least d elements in it. If we choose random Î±1â€‹,Î±1â€‹,â‹¯,Î±nâ€‹ from S, Pr[p(Î±1â€‹,Î±2â€‹,â‹¯,Î±nâ€‹)=0]â‰¤âˆ£Sâˆ£dâ€‹.

In the familiar univariate case p(X), this reduces to saying that a nonzero polynomial of degree d has at most d roots.

The Schwartz-Zippel lemma is used in polynomial equality testing. Given two multi-variate polynomials p1â€‹(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) and p2â€‹(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹) of degrees d1â€‹,d2â€‹ respectively, we can test if p1â€‹(Î±1â€‹,â‹¯,Î±nâ€‹)âˆ’p2â€‹(Î±1â€‹,â‹¯,Î±nâ€‹)=0 for random Î±1â€‹,â‹¯,Î±nâ€‹â†S, where the size of S is at least âˆ£Sâˆ£â‰¥(d1â€‹+d2â€‹). If the two polynomials are identical, this will always be true, whereas if the two polynomials are different then the equality holds with probability at most âˆ£Sâˆ£max(d1â€‹,d2â€‹)â€‹.

Vanishing polynomial

Consider the order-n multiplicative subgroup H with primitive root of unity Ï‰. For all Ï‰iâˆˆH,iâˆˆ[nâˆ’1], we have (Ï‰i)n=(Ï‰n)i=(Ï‰0)i=1. In other words, every element of H fulfils the equation

ZHâ€‹(X)â€‹=Xnâˆ’1=(Xâˆ’Ï‰0)(Xâˆ’Ï‰1)(Xâˆ’Ï‰2)â‹¯(Xâˆ’Ï‰nâˆ’1),â€‹

meaning every element is a root of ZHâ€‹(X). We call ZHâ€‹(X) the vanishing polynomial over H because it evaluates to zero on all elements of H.

This comes in particularly handy when checking polynomial constraints. For instance, to check that A(X)+B(X)=C(X) over H, we simply have to check that A(X)+B(X)âˆ’C(X) is some multiple of ZHâ€‹(X). In other words, if dividing our constraint by the vanishing polynomial still yields some polynomial ZHâ€‹(X)A(X)+B(X)âˆ’C(X)â€‹=H(X), we are satisfied that A(X)+B(X)âˆ’C(X)=0 over H.

Lagrange basis functions

Polynomials are commonly written in the monomial basis (e.g. X,X2,...Xn). However, when working over a multiplicative subgroup of order n, we find a more natural expression in the Lagrange basis.

Consider the order-n multiplicative subgroup H with primitive root of unity Ï‰. The Lagrange basis corresponding to this subgroup is a set of functions {Liâ€‹}i=0nâˆ’1â€‹, where

Liâ€‹(Ï‰j)={10â€‹ifÂ i=j,otherwise.â€‹

We can write this more compactly as Liâ€‹(Ï‰j)=Î´ijâ€‹, where Î´ is the Kronecker delta function.

Now, we can write our polynomial as a linear combination of Lagrange basis functions,

A(X)=i=0âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹aiâ€‹Liâ€‹(X),XâˆˆH,

which is equivalent to saying that p(X) evaluates to a0â€‹ at Ï‰0, to a1â€‹ at Ï‰1, to a2â€‹ at Ï‰2,â‹¯, and so on.

When working over a multiplicative subgroup, the Lagrange basis function has a convenient sparse representation of the form

Liâ€‹(X)=Xâˆ’Ï‰iciâ€‹â‹…(Xnâˆ’1)â€‹,

where ciâ€‹ is the barycentric weight. (To understand how this form was derived, refer to 3.) For i=0, we have c=1/nâŸ¹L0â€‹(X)=n1â€‹Xâˆ’1(Xnâˆ’1)â€‹.

Suppose we are given a set of evaluation points {x0â€‹,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâˆ’1â€‹}. Since we cannot assume that the xiâ€‹'s form a multiplicative subgroup, we consider also the Lagrange polynomials Liâ€‹'s in the general case. Then we can construct:

Liâ€‹(X)=jî€ =iâˆâ€‹xiâ€‹âˆ’xjâ€‹Xâˆ’xjâ€‹â€‹,iâˆˆ[0..nâˆ’1].

Here, every X=xjâ€‹î€ =xiâ€‹ will produce a zero numerator term (xjâ€‹âˆ’xjâ€‹), causing the whole product to evaluate to zero. On the other hand, X=xiâ€‹ will evaluate to xiâ€‹âˆ’xjâ€‹xiâ€‹âˆ’xjâ€‹â€‹ at every term, resulting in an overall product of one. This gives the desired Kronecker delta behaviour Liâ€‹(xjâ€‹)=Î´ijâ€‹ on the set {x0â€‹,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâˆ’1â€‹}.

Lagrange interpolation

Given a polynomial in its evaluation representation

A:{(x0â€‹,A(x0â€‹)),(x1â€‹,A(x1â€‹)),â‹¯,(xnâˆ’1â€‹,A(xnâˆ’1â€‹))},

A(X)=i=0âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹A(xiâ€‹)Liâ€‹(X),

where Xâˆˆ{x0â€‹,x1â€‹,â‹¯,x1âˆ’nâ€‹}.

Cryptographic groups

In the section Inverses and groups we introduced the concept of groups. A group has an identity and a group operation. In this section we will write groups additively, i.e. the identity is O and the group operation is +.

Some groups can be used as cryptographic groups. At the risk of oversimplifying, this means that the problem of finding a discrete logarithm of a group element P to a given base G, i.e. finding x such that P=[x]G, is hard in general.

Pedersen commitment

The Pedersen commitment [P99] is a way to commit to a secret message in a verifiable way. It uses two random public generators G,HâˆˆG, where G is a cryptographic group of order p. A random secret r is chosen in Zqâ€‹, and the message to commit to m is from any subset of Zqâ€‹. The commitment is

c=Commit(m,r)=[m]G+[r]H.

To open the commitment, the committer reveals m and r, thus allowing anyone to verify that c is indeed a commitment to m.

Notice that the Pedersen commitment scheme is homomorphic:

Commit(m,r)+Commit(mâ€²,râ€²)â€‹=[m]G+[r]H+[mâ€²]G+[râ€²]H=[m+mâ€²]G+[r+râ€²]H=Commit(m+mâ€²,r+râ€²).â€‹

Assuming the discrete log assumption holds, Pedersen commitments are also perfectly hiding and computationally binding:

  • hiding: the adversary chooses messages m0â€‹,m1â€‹. The committer commits to one of these messages c=Commit(mbâ€‹;r),bâˆˆ{0,1}. Given c, the probability of the adversary guessing the correct b is no more than 21â€‹.
  • binding: the adversary cannot pick two different messages m0â€‹î€ =m1â€‹, and randomness r0â€‹,r1â€‹, such that Commit(m0â€‹,r0â€‹)=Commit(m1â€‹,r1â€‹).

Vector Pedersen commitment

We can use a variant of the Pedersen commitment scheme to commit to multiple messages at once, m=(m1â€‹,â‹¯,mnâ€‹). This time, we'll have to sample a corresponding number of random public generators G=(G0â€‹,â‹¯,Gnâˆ’1â€‹), along with a single random generator H as before (for use in hiding). Then, our commitment scheme is:

Commit(m;r)â€‹=Commit((m0â€‹,â‹¯,mnâˆ’1â€‹);r)=[r]H+[m0â€‹]G0â€‹+â‹¯+[mnâˆ’1â€‹]Gnâˆ’1â€‹=[r]H+i=0âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹[miâ€‹]Giâ€‹.â€‹

Diffie--Hellman

An example of a protocol that uses cryptographic groups is Diffie--Hellman key agreement [DH1976]. The Diffie--Hellman protocol is a method for two users, Alice and Bob, to generate a shared private key. It proceeds as follows:

  1. Alice and Bob publicly agree on two prime numbers, p and G, where p is large and G is a primitive root (modp). (Note that g is a generator of the group FpÃ—â€‹.)
  2. Alice chooses a large random number a as her private key. She computes her public key A=[a]G(modp), and sends A to Bob.
  3. Similarly, Bob chooses a large random number b as his private key. He computes his public key B=[b]G(modp), and sends B to Alice.
  4. Now both Alice and Bob compute their shared key K=[ab]G(modp), which Alice computes as K=[a]B(modp)=[a]([b]G)(modp), and Bob computes as K=[b]A(modp)=[b]([a]G)(modp).

A potential eavesdropper would need to derive K=[ab]g(modp) knowing only g,p,A=[a]G, and B=[b]G: in other words, they would need to either get the discrete logarithm a from A=[a]G or b from B=[b]G, which we assume to be computationally infeasible in FpÃ—â€‹.

More generally, protocols that use similar ideas to Diffie--Hellman are used throughout cryptography. One way of instantiating a cryptographic group is as an elliptic curve. Before we go into detail on elliptic curves, we'll describe some algorithms that can be used for any group.

Elliptic curves

Elliptic curves constructed over finite fields are another important cryptographic tool.

We use elliptic curves because they provide a cryptographic group, i.e. a group in which the discrete logarithm problem (discussed below) is hard.

There are several ways to define the curve equation, but for our purposes, let Fpâ€‹ be a large (255-bit) field, and then let the set of solutions (x,y) to y2=x3+b for some constant b define the Fpâ€‹-rational points on an elliptic curve E(Fpâ€‹). These (x,y) coordinates are called "affine coordinates". Each of the Fpâ€‹-rational points, together with a "point at infinity" O that serves as the group identity, can be interpreted as an element of a group. By convention, elliptic curve groups are written additively.

"Three points on a line sum to zero, which is the point at infinity."

The group addition law is simple: to add two points together, find the line that intersects both points and obtain the third point, and then negate its y-coordinate. The case that a point is being added to itself, called point doubling, requires special handling: we find the line tangent to the point, and then find the single other point that intersects this line and then negate. Otherwise, in the event that a point is being "added" to its negation, the result is the point at infinity.

The ability to add and double points naturally gives us a way to scale them by integers, called scalars. The number of points on the curve is the group order. If this number is a prime q, then the scalars can be considered as elements of a scalar field, Fqâ€‹.

Elliptic curves, when properly designed, have an important security property. Given two random elements G,HâˆˆE(Fpâ€‹) finding a such that [a]G=H, otherwise known as the discrete log of H with respect to G, is considered computationally infeasible with classical computers. This is called the elliptic curve discrete log assumption.

If an elliptic curve group G has prime order q (like the ones used in Halo 2), then it is a finite cyclic group. Recall from the section on groups that this implies it is isomorphic to Z/qZ, or equivalently, to the scalar field Fqâ€‹. Each possible generator G fixes the isomorphism; then an element on the scalar side is precisely the discrete log of the corresponding group element with respect to G. In the case of a cryptographically secure elliptic curve, the isomorphism is hard to compute in the Gâ†’Fqâ€‹ direction because the elliptic curve discrete log problem is hard.

It is sometimes helpful to make use of this isomorphism by thinking of group-based cryptographic protocols and algorithms in terms of the scalars instead of in terms of the group elements. This can make proofs and notation simpler.

For instance, it has become common in papers on proof systems to use the notation [x] to denote a group element with discrete log x, where the generator is implicit.

We also used this idea in the "distinct-x theorem", in order to prove correctness of optimizations for elliptic curve scalar multiplication in Sapling, and an endomorphism-based optimization in Appendix C of the original Halo paper.

Curve arithmetic

Point doubling

The simplest situation is doubling a point (x0â€‹,y0â€‹). Continuing with our example y2=x3+b, this is done first by computing the derivative Î»=dxdyâ€‹=2y3x2â€‹.

Projective coordinates

This unfortunately requires an expensive inversion of 2y. We can avoid this by arranging our equations to "defer" the computation of the inverse, since we often do not need the actual affine (xâ€²,yâ€²) coordinate of the resulting point immediately after an individual curve operation. Let's introduce a third coordinate Z and scale our curve equation by Z3 like so:

Z3y2=Z3x3+Z3b

Our original curve is just this curve at the restriction Z=1. If we allow the affine point (x,y) to be represented by X=xZ, Y=yZ and Zî€ =0 then we have the homogenous projective curve

Y2Z=X3+Z3b.

Obtaining (x,y) from (X,Y,Z) is as simple as computing (X/Z,Y/Z) when Zî€ =0. (When Z=0, we are dealing with the point at infinity O:=(0:1:0).) In this form, we now have a convenient way to defer the inversion required by doubling a point. The general strategy is to express xâ€²,yâ€² as rational functions using x=X/Z and y=Y/Z, rearrange to make their denominators the same, and then take the resulting point (X,Y,Z) to have Z be the shared denominator and X=xâ€²Z,Y=yâ€²Z.

Projective coordinates are often, but not always, more efficient than affine coordinates. There may be exceptions to this when either we have a different way to apply Montgomery's trick, or when we're in the circuit setting where multiplications and inversions are about equally as expensive (at least in terms of circuit size).

The following shows an example of doubling a point (X,Y,Z)=(xZ,yZ,Z) without an inversion. Substituting with X,Y,Z gives us Î»=2y3x2â€‹=2(Y/Z)3(X/Z)2â€‹=2YZ3X2â€‹

and gives us xâ€²yâ€²â€‹=Î»2âˆ’2x=Î»2âˆ’Z2Xâ€‹=4Y2Z29X4â€‹âˆ’Z2Xâ€‹=4Y2Z29X4âˆ’8XY2Zâ€‹=8Y3Z318X4YZâˆ’16XY3Z2â€‹=Î»(xâˆ’xâ€²)âˆ’y=Î»(ZXâ€‹âˆ’4Y2Z29X4âˆ’8XY2Zâ€‹)âˆ’ZYâ€‹=2YZ3X2â€‹(ZXâ€‹âˆ’4Y2Z29X4âˆ’8XY2Zâ€‹)âˆ’ZYâ€‹=2YZ23X3â€‹âˆ’8Y3Z327X6âˆ’24X3Y2Zâ€‹âˆ’ZYâ€‹=8Y3Z312X3Y2Zâˆ’8Y4Z2âˆ’27X6+24X3Y2Zâ€‹â€‹

Notice how the denominators of xâ€² and yâ€² are the same. Thus, instead of computing (xâ€²,yâ€²) we can compute (X,Y,Z) with Z=8Y3Z3 and X,Y set to the corresponding numerators such that X/Z=xâ€² and Y/Z=yâ€². This completely avoids the need to perform an inversion when doubling, and something analogous to this can be done when adding two distinct points.

Point addition

We now add two points with distinct x-coordinates, P=(x0â€‹,y0â€‹) and Q=(x1â€‹,y1â€‹), where x0â€‹î€ =x1â€‹, to obtain R=P+Q=(x2â€‹,y2â€‹). The line PQâ€‹ has slope Î»=fracy1â€‹âˆ’y0â€‹x1â€‹âˆ’x0â€‹âŸ¹yâˆ’y0â€‹=Î»â‹…(xâˆ’x0â€‹).

Using the expression for PQâ€‹, we compute y-coordinate âˆ’y2â€‹ of âˆ’R as: âˆ’y2â€‹âˆ’y0â€‹=Î»â‹…(x2â€‹âˆ’x0â€‹)âŸ¹y2â€‹=(x0â€‹âˆ’x2â€‹)âˆ’y0â€‹â€‹.

Plugging the expression for PQâ€‹ into the curve equation y2=x3+b yields y2=x3+bâ€‹âŸ¹(Î»â‹…(xâˆ’x0â€‹)+y0â€‹)2=x3+bâŸ¹x3âˆ’Î»2x2+â‹¯=0â†(rearrangingÂ terms)=(xâˆ’x0â€‹)(xâˆ’x1â€‹)(xâˆ’x2â€‹)â†(knownÂ rootsÂ x0â€‹,x1â€‹,x2â€‹)=x3âˆ’(x0â€‹+x1â€‹+x2â€‹)x2+â‹¯.â€‹

Comparing coefficients for the x2 term gives us Î»2=x0â€‹+x1â€‹+x2â€‹âŸ¹x2â€‹=Î»2âˆ’x0â€‹âˆ’x1â€‹â€‹.

Important notes:

  • There exist efficient formulae1 for point addition that do not have edge cases (so-called "complete" formulae) and that unify the addition and doubling cases together. The result of adding a point to its negation using those formulae produces Z=0, which represents the point at infinity.
  • In addition, there are other models like the Jacobian representation where (x,y)=(xZ2,yZ3,Z) where the curve is rescaled by Z6 instead of Z3, and this representation has even more efficient arithmetic but no unified/complete formulae.
  • We can easily compare two curve points (X1â€‹,Y1â€‹,Z1â€‹) and (X2â€‹,Y2â€‹,Z2â€‹) for equality in the homogenous projective coordinate space by "homogenizing" their Z-coordinates; the checks become X1â€‹Z2â€‹=X2â€‹Z1â€‹ and Y1â€‹Z2â€‹=Y2â€‹Z1â€‹.

Curve endomorphisms

Imagine that Fpâ€‹ has a primitive cube root of unity, or in other words that 3âˆ£pâˆ’1 and so an element Î¶pâ€‹ generates a 3-order multiplicative subgroup. Notice that a point (x,y) on our example elliptic curve y2=x3+b has two cousin points: (Î¶pâ€‹x,Î¶p2â€‹x), because the computation x3 effectively kills the Î¶ component of the x-coordinate. Applying the map (x,y)â†¦(Î¶pâ€‹x,y) is an application of an endomorphism over the curve. The exact mechanics involved are complicated, but when the curve has a prime q number of points (and thus a prime "order") the effect of the endomorphism is to multiply the point by a scalar in Fqâ€‹ which is also a primitive cube root Î¶qâ€‹ in the scalar field.

Curve point compression

Given a point on the curve P=(x,y), we know that its negation âˆ’P=(x,âˆ’y) is also on the curve. To uniquely specify a point, we need only encode its x-coordinate along with the sign of its y-coordinate.

Serialization

As mentioned in the Fields section, we can interpret the least significant bit of a field element as its "sign", since its additive inverse will always have the opposite LSB. So we record the LSB of the y-coordinate as sign.

Pallas and Vesta are defined over the Fpâ€‹ and Fqâ€‹ fields, which elements can be expressed in 255 bits. This conveniently leaves one unused bit in a 32-byte representation. We pack the y-coordinate sign bit into the highest bit in the representation of the x-coordinate:

         <----------------------------------- x --------------------------------->
Enc(P) = [_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _] [_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _] ... [_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _] [_ _ _ _ _ _ _ sign]
          ^                <------------------------------------->                 ^
         LSB                              30 bytes                                MSB

The "point at infinity" O that serves as the group identity, does not have an affine (x,y) representation. However, it turns out that there are no points on either the Pallas or Vesta curve with x=0 or y=0. We therefore use the "fake" affine coordinates (0,0) to encode O, which results in the all-zeroes 32-byte array.

Deserialization

When deserializing a compressed curve point, we first read the most significant bit as ysign, the sign of the y-coordinate. Then, we set this bit to zero to recover the original x-coordinate.

If x=0,y=0, we return the "point at infinity" O. Otherwise, we proceed to compute y=x3+bâ€‹. Here, we read the least significant bit of y as sign. If sign == ysign, we already have the correct sign and simply return the curve point (x,y). Otherwise, we negate y and return (x,âˆ’y).

Cycles of curves

Let Epâ€‹ be an elliptic curve over a finite field Fpâ€‹, where p is a prime. We denote this by Epâ€‹/Fpâ€‹. and we denote the group of points of Epâ€‹ over Fpâ€‹, with order q=#E(Fpâ€‹). For this curve, we call Fpâ€‹ the "base field" and Fqâ€‹ the "scalar field".

We instantiate our proof system over the elliptic curve Epâ€‹/Fpâ€‹. This allows us to prove statements about Fqâ€‹-arithmetic circuit satisfiability.

(aside) If our curve Epâ€‹ is over Fpâ€‹, why is the arithmetic circuit instead in Fqâ€‹? The proof system is basically working on encodings of the scalars in the circuit (or more precisely, commitments to polynomials whose coefficients are scalars). The scalars are in Fqâ€‹ when their encodings/commitments are elliptic curve points in Epâ€‹/Fpâ€‹.

However, most of the verifier's arithmetic computations are over the base field Fpâ€‹, and are thus efficiently expressed as an Fpâ€‹-arithmetic circuit.

(aside) Why are the verifier's computations (mainly) over Fpâ€‹? The Halo 2 verifier actually has to perform group operations using information output by the circuit. Group operations like point doubling and addition use arithmetic in Fpâ€‹, because the coordinates of points are in Fpâ€‹.

This motivates us to construct another curve with scalar field Fpâ€‹, which has an Fpâ€‹-arithmetic circuit that can efficiently verify proofs from the first curve. As a bonus, if this second curve had base field Eqâ€‹/Fqâ€‹, it would generate proofs that could be efficiently verified in the first curve's Fqâ€‹-arithmetic circuit. In other words, we instantiate a second proof system over Eqâ€‹/Fqâ€‹, forming a 2-cycle with the first:

Hashing to curves

Sometimes it is useful to be able to produce a random point on an elliptic curve Epâ€‹/Fpâ€‹ corresponding to some input, in such a way that no-one will know its discrete logarithm (to any other base).

This is described in detail in the Internet draft on Hashing to Elliptic Curves. Several algorithms can be used depending on efficiency and security requirements. The framework used in the Internet Draft makes use of several functions:

  • hash_to_field: takes a byte sequence input and maps it to a element in the base field Fpâ€‹
  • map_to_curve: takes an Fpâ€‹ element and maps it to Epâ€‹.

Polynomial commitment using inner product argument

We want to commit to some polynomial p(X)âˆˆFpâ€‹[X], and be able to provably evaluate the committed polynomial at arbitrary points. The naive solution would be for the prover to simply send the polynomial's coefficients to the verifier: however, this requires O(n) communication. Our polynomial commitment scheme gets the job done using O(logn) communication.

Setup

Given a parameter d=2k, we generate the common reference string Ïƒ=(G,G,H,Fpâ€‹) defining certain constants for this scheme:

  • G is a group of prime order p;
  • GâˆˆGd is a vector of d random group elements;
  • HâˆˆG is a random group element; and
  • Fpâ€‹ is the finite field of order p.

Commit

The Pedersen vector commitment Commit is defined as

Commit(Ïƒ,p(X);r)=âŸ¨a,GâŸ©+[r]H,

for some polynomial p(X)âˆˆFpâ€‹[X] and some blinding factor râˆˆFpâ€‹. Here, each element of the vector aiâ€‹âˆˆFpâ€‹ is the coefficient for the ith degree term of p(X), and p(X) is of maximal degree dâˆ’1.

Open (prover) and OpenVerify (verifier)

The modified inner product argument is an argument of knowledge for the relation

{((P,x,v);(a,r)):P=âŸ¨a,GâŸ©+[r]H,v=âŸ¨a,bâŸ©}â€‹,

where b=(1,x,x2,â‹¯,xdâˆ’1) is composed of increasing powers of the evaluation point x. This allows a prover to demonstrate to a verifier that the polynomial contained â€œinsideâ€ the commitment P evaluates to v at x, and moreover, that the committed polynomial has maximum degree dâˆ’1.

The inner product argument proceeds in k=log2â€‹d rounds. For our purposes, it is sufficient to know about its final outputs, while merely providing intuition about the intermediate rounds. (Refer to Section 3 in the Halo paper for a full explanation.)

Before beginning the argument, the verifier selects a random group element U and sends it to the prover. We initialize the argument at round k, with the vectors a(k):=a, G(k):=G and b(k):=b. In each round j=k,kâˆ’1,â‹¯,1:

  • the prover computes two values Ljâ€‹ and Rjâ€‹ by taking some inner product of a(j) with G(j) and b(j). Note that are in some sense "cross-terms": the lower half of a is used with the higher half of G and b, and vice versa:

Ljâ€‹Rjâ€‹â€‹=âŸ¨alo(j)â€‹,Ghi(j)â€‹âŸ©+[ljâ€‹]H+[âŸ¨alo(j)â€‹,bhi(j)â€‹âŸ©]U=âŸ¨ahi(j)â€‹,Glo(j)â€‹âŸ©+[ljâ€‹]H+[âŸ¨ahi(j)â€‹,blo(j)â€‹âŸ©]Uâ€‹

  • the verifier issues a random challenge ujâ€‹;
  • the prover uses ujâ€‹ to compress the lower and higher halves of a(j), thus producing a new vector of half the original length a(jâˆ’1)=ahi(j)â€‹â‹…ujâˆ’1â€‹+alo(j)â€‹â‹…ujâ€‹. The vectors G(j) and b(j) are similarly compressed to give G(jâˆ’1) and b(jâˆ’1).
  • a(jâˆ’1), G(jâˆ’1) and b(jâˆ’1) are input to the next round jâˆ’1.

Note that at the end of the last round j=1, we are left with a:=a(0), G:=G(0), b:=b(0), each of length 1. The intuition is that these final scalars, together with the challenges {ujâ€‹} and "cross-terms" {Ljâ€‹,Rjâ€‹} from each round, encode the compression in each round. Since the prover did not know the challenges U,{ujâ€‹} in advance, they would have been unable to manipulate the round compressions. Thus, checking a constraint on these final terms should enforce that the compression had been performed correctly, and that the original a satisfied the relation before undergoing compression.

Note that G,b are simply rearrangements of the publicly known G,b, with the round challenges {ujâ€‹} mixed in: this means the verifier can compute G,b independently and verify that the prover had provided those same values.

Recursion

Alternative terms: Induction; Accumulation scheme; Proof-carrying data

However, the computation of G requires a length-2k multiexponentiation âŸ¨G,sâŸ©, where s is composed of the round challenges u1â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€‹ arranged in a binary counting structure. This is the linear-time computation that we want to amortise across a batch of proof instances. Instead of computing G, notice that we can express G as a commitment to a polynomial

G=Commit(Ïƒ,g(X,u1â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€‹)),

where g(X,u1â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€‹):=âˆi=1kâ€‹(uiâ€‹+uiâˆ’1â€‹X2iâˆ’1) is a polynomial with degree 2kâˆ’1.

Since G is a commitment, it can be checked in an inner product argument. The verifier circuit witnesses G and brings G,u1â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€‹ out as public inputs to the proof Ï€. The next verifier instance checks Ï€ using the inner product argument; this includes checking that G=Commit(g(X,u1â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€‹)) evaluates at some random point to the expected value for the given challenges u1â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€‹. Recall from the previous section that this check only requires logd work.

At the end of checking Ï€ and G, the circuit is left with a new Gâ€², along with the u1â€²â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€²â€‹ challenges sampled for the check. To fully accept Ï€ as valid, we should perform a linear-time computation of Gâ€²=âŸ¨G,sâ€²âŸ©. Once again, we delay this computation by witnessing Gâ€² and bringing G,u1â€‹,â‹¯,ukâ€‹ out as public inputs to the proof Ï€.

This goes on from one proof instance to the next, until we are satisfied with the size of our batch of proofs. We finally perform a single linear-time computation, thus deciding the validity of the whole batch.

We recall from the section Cycles of curves that we can instantiate this protocol over a two-cycle, where a proof produced by one curve is efficiently verified in the circuit of the other curve. However, some of these verifier checks can actually be efficiently performed in the native circuit; these are "deferred" to the next native circuit (see diagram below) instead of being immediately passed over to the other curve.
